Getting Started

Source: vignettes/getting-started.Rmd
getting-started.Rmd

Short version

Are you a user wanting to fully master the grammar of ggplot2? Start here!

Are you an aspiring developer wanting to extend ggplot2? Start here!

Long version

There’s a lot that can be said about ggplot internals, and what you can get from using ggtrace depends on how comfortable you are with ggplot2 and ggplot internals. Whether you’re here because you want to become a better ggplot user or because you’re an aspiring extension developer, ggtrace has you covered for all stages of your ggplot2 journey!

Stage 0 (user)

If this is your first time hearing about ggplot internals, I recommend starting with part 1 of my blog post series on delayed aesthetic evaluation, a case study of somewhat niche {ggplot2} functions that lie at the intersection between user-facing code and ggplot internals. You might also want to start with another blog post of mine on stat_*() layers, for extra scaffolding. These will give you minimal background on ggplot internals to get started.

Stage 1 (advanced user)

Then, you can watch my rstudio::conf(2022) talk on {ggtrace} and ggplot internals. If that felt a little too fast/dense, you can watch a slower (hour-long), broken down version of me covering the same content. This is where I showcase the inspect family of workflow functions in ggtrace and you also will be introduced to ggproto. The talk(s) essentially covers the contents of Chapter 20.2 of the ggplot2 book, but with emphasis on practicality for the user. I’d actually recommend reading the entire book chapter anyways (or read it with a recording of me going over Part 1 and Part 2 of the chapter), as it covers many fundamental concepts that may come off as unintuitive at first. As you read through it, I highly recommend referencing Emi Tanaka’s awesome slides on ggplot2 internals and Bob Rudis’s short chapter on demystifying ggplot2 as companion guides.

Stage 2 (aspiring developer)

If you’re not scared away by ggproto methods and want to keep exploring the internals, you should continue by watching Thomas Lin Pedersen’s rstudio::conf(2020) talk on extending ggplot, which gives a nice overview of what kind of ggproto methods exist and what the most relevant ones are / what they do. Now you’re entering developer territory. In case you want a more comprehensive documentation on ggproto (though not necessary to read them at this stage), check out the package vignette on ggproto and Brodie Gaslam’s even more comprehensive unofficial reference for ggplot internals.

You can follow up on Thomas’s talk by watching my useR! 2022 talk on {ggtrace} and ggplot internals, which showcases all workflows in ggtrace (inspect, capture, highjack) for interacting with ggproto methods. The part 2 of my blog post series on delayed aesthetic evaluation picks up where I left off in that talk to expand on the possible extension points to different Stat methods.

That leads nicely into the case study chapter of the ggplot2 book. It’s a huge chapter, so if you want some diversity you can also reference Emi’s slides on writing ggplot2 extensions ggplot and read the package vignette on extending ggplot side-by-side, which touches on the same topics but with different examples. In the process, you’ll inevitably encounter {grid}, which is itself a whole ’nother monster. There are a lot of resources on {grid}, most notably Paul’s book R Graphics (3rd edition), but there are also some resources written with ggplot internals in mind, like yet another one of Emi’s slides, and functions for interacting with gtable objects from {lemon} and {gridExtra}.

Stage 4 (developer)

At this point you know enough internals to go off and write your own extensions. You are now a developer (even if you’re just starting!) - your training wheels are off and you’re in the territory of figuring things out for yourself. A few people have written on the topic of debugging ggplot, including Hiroaki Yutani’s blog post on using browser() for debugging ggproto methods and Dewey Dunnington’s {ggdebug} package which gives you freakishly powerful control over the internals. People have also written packages for less “intrusive” ways of debugging and interacting with the internals, including {gginnards} by Pedro J. Aphalo and {gggrid} by Paul Murrell.

Standing on the shoulders of these giants, ggtrace aims to offer the best of both worlds, with high-level workflow functions in the form of ggtrace_{action}_{value}(), the low-level functions ggtrace() and with_ggtrace(), and the interactive debugging functions ggedit() and ggdebugonce(). There’s not a whole lot of new stuff that ggtrace offers in this space (the package isn’t even that much code) but it embodies a transformative reframing of ggplot internals as functional programming, the kind that we’re familiar with as R users. I hope this overview of what people have written about ggplot internals over the years can compensate for the (at least current) lack of vignettes in the package.

Lastly, ggplot2 is always evolving! It might not be obvious as users, but the internals are undergoing constant change. So at some point you might also want to start keeping an eye on the Github issues. It’s also a nice place to be because you can eavesdrop on the thoughts and insights from the core developers (e.g., should users be able to specify pieces of a scale_*() modularly?, should the guides system be converted to ggproto?, should layers get “state”?), which can actually directly help you understand the motivation behind how and why things in the internals are designed that way.
